Okay, out of pure boredom, I decided to write a full review about every specific thing in the game.  If you just came here to know everything about the game before you buy it, I would highly recommend you to buy it, but I think I should head over to the cons before anything.  If you can relate to these things being bad, or unenjoyable, then you may need to reconsider buying this game. - 8-bit (or 16-bit, whatever, OR 24-BIT, WHATEVER) graphics. If you dislike those kind of graphics, remember that the whole game is pixelated. - Very difficult. If you’re a person who is overall bad at games, or like specific game styles, remember that everything in the game is very, very, VERY difficult, unforgiving, and did I mentioned that it’s difficult? You will die all the time and I mean it. - Very fast-pasted. If you’re a casual gamer who enjoys gameplay that involves no stress at all, you should definitely reconsider buying this game. - No multiplayer.  If none of the things I just mentioned don’t bother you, I would REALLY recommend you to play this game. Okay, now when that is out of the way, let’s talk about specific aspects. 1. Gameplay It has a top-down perspective. (Look at the screenshots if you don’t understand.) Where you kill people with melees and guns. You can throw them, too, which is unique compared to most games that feature guns. Throwing the guns at a person resorts in knocking them down, and you execute them by pressing the space bar. If you have no melee equipped, you will need to left-click a few times before you kill the enemy. But if you wait a short while, the enemy will get up, equip the nearest weapon he can see, and will try to attack you again. There are enemies that require weapons, such as dogs, fat guys, and dodgers.  Also, a very significant thing about the gameplay is that you get to choose a mask with different abilities. Want dogs not to attack you? Choose Ted. Want to make the enemies not hear the gunshots, and just kill them one-by-one? Choose Peter. Want to kill enemies just by throwing the guns? Choose Jake. You get the point. 2. Visuals  They’re 24-bit, but they’re very detailed for a pixelated game (especially the faces that appear whilst dialogue). And if you’re a fan of gore in videogames, then you will definitely enjoy this game, considering that this is one of the goriest games that I’ve ever played. Okay, I’m not too much of a gamer, but my point is that the game is gory, especially in the second game. 3. Story Sorry, I can’t summarise the story chronologically in a few sentences, but it’s interesting, dark, mysterious, and confusing. Google search it if you want to. It won’t spoil anything, it’s hard to put the puzzle pieces together when playing the game. The first game has barely any story comparing to the sequel, and it constantly takes different roles and time periods.  4. Music If you would ask anyone who has played Hotline Miami what stands out about this game, one of the first answers would be the music. It really gives you the atmosphere that the game takes place. In my opinion, Hotline Miami 2’s soundtrack is much better, but a lot of the songs used in the first game are very iconic and popular.  Thank you if you actually read this.

Now I can tell you one thing... This is a must have for shooter fans. Hotline miami bought me nothing but fun solid gameplay. With a clever story and intense gameplay you will drool as you see all your victims lie on the ground dead. Objective? KILL EVERYONE  Story: Game as a very clever plot if you dig in. I will tell you a bit of the story, you play as an unnamed protagonist (dubbed 'Jacket') who starts getting unknown phone calls that are basically telling him to go to locations and kill Russian mobsters/mafia. As you continue to kill you start losing insanity trying to make out what is real or not. This is as much info as I will tell you. But the backstory and secrets will shock you to the core.  Gameplay: This is a fast paced game. If you can't react fast or think fast then this isn't a game for you. In this game you wear masks to aid you when killing people, they can either boost your speed, assist you with guns or even gain you more points. The executions are brutal where you smash heads and stab people, this game is not for the faint hearted! The enemies react and attempt to kill you on sight but they aren't smart. Melee enemies are easy to take out since your fists are enough to get the dropped weapon and enemies with gun are a challenge but I think you can manage that. Overall fast and fun gameplay  Art: The art is nice and decent. The art is simple and not to pretty. The sprites for main characters are nicely made and simple, the russian mobsters sprites have one same look (they are all bald). The level design are simple design but there are some good designs and colours. But the face portrait for when the characters are talking are well done! And lets not forget about the blood. This game has a habit of being really messy and bloody and I really like that. YOU CAN SEE HUMAN BRAINS THEY ARE SO REAL 76/10! But the design alright its not good looking but I like it that way!  Music: Has to be one of the best soundtracks I have heard in a video game. The music fits in well with each level I play and I can really feel the rush. Some are intense, some a good to dance to and some a great for relaxing after slaughting your enemies. There isn't any rock or pop its club or DJ music. I really enjoyed listening to the music and you will too.  Negative: One thing that I will say this... what you are doing is so evil and bad that its not funny. And I am saying that for people who are thinking of getting this game cause I love bloody games with blood and gore.   Conclusion: This wasn't a long review but decent review. For two developers this is really impressive. But if you are really thinking of getting this game then you should buy this without thinking. This game deserves $10! MIAMI FOREVER   Note: Sadly for you aussie gamers... hotline miami will not be coming to Australia due to ONE ♥♥♥♥ SCENE! You could skip that scene, it was pretty much the only one and it was poorly made. The developers said you should just pirate the game which is a shame cause I really want to be it with my own money.

Hotline Miami is a game about someone going around and murdering people. Sort of.  It is a top-down run and gun styled game, where one hit will kill you. So you don't really want to play it like a run and gun game, or you'll die much more, the game awards you for being reckless and making up plans as you go.  The story can be rather confusing if you don't play the sequel, but it does not detract from the game, if anything, it makes it even more interesting and intriguing.  But the best thing about this game is the feeling of being a murderer. Not even kidding. They do this so perfectly, I don't know how they managed. The game has a pixel art style, and the violence is amazingly brutal, but the violence isn't as bad since it is in pixels.  I feel like this represents being a killer in the best way, the art style represents being desensitized to the violence around you, you care less about murdering these people in the brutal and horrific ways.  This, pared with the music, fills you will adrenaline and gets you wanting to kill a building full of people.  That one thing made me so happy to buy this game, it affectively made me connect with a character that is nowhere near related to me. This character doesn't even talk, and I got attached.  So, I believe if you like fast-paced brutal action, Hotline Miami is the game for you.

Hotline Miami is a classic example that you shouldn’t judge a game by its cover. First impressions from screenshots and videos may leave you thinking of it as a run of the mill, top-down shooter where you blast baddies with guns (with some ultra-violence mixed in); end of story. But if you aren’t familiar with what it actually  is , as I was not, then the reality is that Hotline Miami is something much more thrilling, intricate, and insightful than what your initial impression probably suggests. Not only is the action unique and fast paced, it is all accented with an outstanding soundtrack and surprisingly smart narrative in this stellar game by Devolver Digital.  Hotline Miami has you playing in late 1980's Miami, controlling a character who receives phone calls from a mysterious antagonist of sorts. Each phone call provides you with a target to assassinate, who is usually tucked away in a building behind all manner of bodyguards and thugs. Typically you start the level with no more than your fists, but you can steal melee weapons and guns from bad guys to unleash carnage more efficiently. As more missions are completed, newer masks (which can grant you passive buffs) are unlocked, as well as new weapons.   The brilliant twist in Hotline Miami is that enemies move and react at a breakneck pace, and your character dies in a single shot or melee hit. The result is that many levels will have you dying dozens of times if you want to run the level efficiently and with a good score -- thankfully Hotline Miami spends virtually zero time between your death and the start of your next run. Clearing a level feels like a perfectly orchestrated heist of brutality and cunning. It’s very similar to something like Super Meat Boy in that regard, but the gameplay itself is different in a very refreshing and unique way.  In most top-down shooters, you wouldn't expect much in the way of narrative. Hotline Miami doesn't have a stand-out narrative and it’s certainly not the focus here, but I was impressed with the way Devolver Digital used small environmental changes to make large implications to the player. These small breadcrumbs build up to a pretty compelling plot; I found myself attached to a character who speaks virtually no dialogue. It helps that the mood is set so perfectly in Hotline Miami; the music is absolutely perfect for every scene (and amazing on its own as well), and the gritty, colorful graphics create a very realized setting for the action taking place.  One thing worth mentioning is that Hotline Miami is an insanely brutal and violent game. It’s intentionally over the top and discomforting, and frequently your hand will be forced to perform some gratuitous acts against questionably innocent people without reason. What’s unexpected is that HM makes some extraordinary comments on violence in games for those who follow the relatively abstract story. For those interested who have beat the game (or don’t mind some spoilers), I would highly recommend reading Rami Ismail’s excellent article on Gamasutra entitled “Why Hotline Miami is an Important Game.”   That said, you don’t really need to care about the underlying message to enjoy Hotline Miami. It is a rollercoaster of high-octane, violence fueled fun, with some commentary if you care enough about it. The length and difficulty are just right, and it’s hard not to have a smile on your face as you slowly put together your perfect, bloody infiltration to the fantastic soundtrack. Truly, Hotline Miami is one of the most complete and enjoyable games you can play on PC today -- check it out.

I recently played Hotline Miami and had good fun with it. The idea is simple: you are a criminal and you need to do a number of missions which invariably consist in killing everybody in a building. You can use a wide range of weapons to do that, and even your bare hands.   Let's be clear: the plot is not a strength of the game. You will die several times (the easiest achievement to get for me was the 'Die 1000 times' one!), and in the process you will learn how to beat the levels. Basically, you need to learn how to ambush the enemies and kill them before they kill you.  Sounds boring, right? It's not! You will enjoy a fantastic soundtrack, you will try many ways to ambush your enemies, you will wear different masks which grant you different powers (such as more ammo, killing fists...), you will see a lot of blood (a lot!), and you will also have the chance to beat a few bosses. It took me roughly 7 hours to finish the game, and then there is a bit of replay value if you want to unlock all guns and masks to see everything that the game has to offer.  As far as I can tell, you cannot change the difficulty level and as I said, the game is hard (the number of deaths proves it) but fair. So... ready to kill?

I can't remember when I bought Hotline Miami or how much I gave for it, but I honestly regret not playing it sooner. I also forget how long it took to finish and to get the secret ending, but I clocked in 10 hours to do all that and get a few additional cheevos.   Hotline Miami is basically Ultraviolence: The Game. Each chapter sees you as the brutally-violent 'Jacket' who dons an animal mask at the start of each level, who then proceeds to slay a bunch of guys in nice white suits while pulsing music plays through the brightly-colored rooms. You're going to leave one hell of a mess, but you have to do it without getting hit. Using the weapons lying around and in the enemy's hands (or your own bare hands), slaughter everyone. Die, and you have to restart the current floor no matter how many mooks' brains you left ground into the carpet before.   Hotline Miami plays like a twin-stick shooter with one stick or WASD to move, and the other stick or the mouse to aim. You don't have many actions but you honestly don't need much. You move at a set rate, you can move the camera slightly away from you to peek around the map, you can punch enemies down, you can finish off downed enemies, you can lock onto individual targets, you can pick up, use, and throw weapons, and you can interact with a few contextual things during your missions. You press R or the A button when you inevitably die to restart the floor. The game doesn't demand perfection but it does ask for accuracy, and being a few degrees off on your swing can be the difference between killing or being killed.   You might look at the screenshots and think the game a rather stylized stealth game. You can sneak around and off enemies with silent melee weapons, but the game encourages you to be reckless and ballsy with the scoring system. Playing it safe and going slowly will net you few points. Killing chains of enemies in a short time gives you bonus combo points, so be quick! Score high and you unlock new weapons and new masks which give minor bonuses like having lethal fists, moving faster, or making all guns silent. The game is very actiony and very fast-paced, and I'd honestly say it has some puzzle elements too. Enemies tend to stick to their rooms and some will patrol in set patterns, so it's a matter of how to dispatch them all quickly but safely. The game also slowly introduces new elements to keep the gameplay fresh, like doors to slam into enemies, or enemies that certain weapons won't work on, or windows that you (and the enemies) can shoot through. Trying to plan your next move while keeping all of these things in mind while your adrenaline's up is only part of the fun.   The story is...minimal, but the experience is very trippy and weird. You're some blonde dude wearing an animal mask and a letterman jacket (hence the nickname). You don't talk, you don't have a name, you just wake up, answer the answering machine, go to some place, and kill a bunch of people. You get a score tally, you unlock things, you go visit your friend at one of the stores he works at, and then you go home to repeat the process. It's a very arcadey experience since the story is so out of focus. You'll be left with plenty of questions if you stop to think...but who has time for that? You might be able to piece together the puzzle if you have an eye for detail.   While each chapter doesn't have its own unique song, the music really helps to get you in the killing mood. High-tempo music just goes well with the frantic pace of you moving through the rooms, mowing down scores of mooks. You might find yourself bobbing your head to the beat or tapping your foot or whatever. Then you get Chapter Clear and the music... stops.  Party's over, time to go home.   The game is pretty short. Most of your time with this game will be spent getting that 'perfect' run through each stage and chapter, so you'll be repeating content quite a bit until you stop dying. The game's hard, but I didn't think it crossed over from 'challenging but fun' to 'frustrating and disheartening.' The individual stages within the chapters are thankfully pretty short, so you rarely lose any big chunk of time to failure. If you're the type of person who likes to speedrun levels or try to beat your previous score or beat your friends' scores or are just an old-fashioned cheevo-♥♥♥♥♥, there's something here for you. And there's always some catharsis in cutting a bunch of mooks in half with a katana.   I'd like to think that Hotline Miami is well-deserving of its high praise, but it might not be a game for everyone. Some people might be turned off by the almost cartoonish pixelated gore they'd be creating, some people might not care for the whatever-genre-it-is music, and some people might want to snap their keyboards and controllers in half after dying for the 30th time in a row. For everyone else, it'll be a difficult but rewarding ride filled with lots of death. Maybe you  do  like hurting people.

Blood splashes everywhere, bits of brain go flying, and those that aren’t instantly killed by your weapon can be strangled to death. Hotline Miami is this generation’s Postal, but without the tongue-in-cheek preface, and even more indefensible in terms of its content. But that’s the point, really. Oddly reminiscent of Dreamweb (1994), if only for its top-down perspective and dark violence, Hotline Miami is a moment-to-moment heart-pounding pixel-perfect murder simulator.   A strange phone call with instructions in code sends you to a location: a house, a club, an apartment building. You choose which mask to wear (each one with special attributes), and try to kill everyone inside. Every shot is deadly, for both you and the mobster-types you decimate. Death is instant, often so fast only the “PRESS R TO RESTART” giving you a clue that you’re dead. Controls are simple, left click to attack (punch, shoot, stab), contextual to what weapon you have in your hands. Right click to pick up what’s on the floor, or to throw what you’re carrying.   The more creative you are in your spree, the higher the grade and score at the end of a mission. Score unlocks new masks, and new weapons that may drop from enemies (kinda like Super Crate Box). But why are you killing, and who is on the other end of the phone call?

This game is one of my most favorite games. It's simplistic, yet offers so many ways to go about beating each arcade style level. The design is impeccable, with the modernization of today's gameplay techniques and lack of censorship, blending harmoniously with the retro 80's aesthetic of yesteryear, which has always suggested something darker lies underneath. The music is like the modern age is tapping an oil well into your primal instincts and just gets you pumped up to start murdering things, which I find particularly liberating. I highly recommend the soundtrack.  The game's strategies appeal to both the casual and the hardcore, and use the trial and error form of gameplay to teach players what works and what doesn't. If you want to use the guns as luring mechanisms so that the enemies come to easily and you can just slash them up with a knife, then you can. If you want to don the Tony or Brian mask and speedrun a level to get the highest possible score, then you can do that too. Whatever the case may be, anyone can play this game their own way, and that's the bread and butter of any game.  I personally found the hospital level to be gimmicky and dull, despite its attempt at being something of a story intermission. But all in all, this game will remain one of my favorites for years to come.  - Patrick Bateman

This game is frustratingly difficult, occasionally hard to control and sometimes confusing. But you know what? I had a blast with it throughout it's entirety. For me (I got the game on sale for 2.50$) this game was worth every penny, and would've been worth it even if I got it full price. Hotline Miami is a top-down beat em' up with a great soundtrack set in Miami in the 80s. This game was super fun to play, I found myself getting frustrated as enemies rushed me from every direction to kill me, only to not be able to put the game down. I would go through every level probably at least 20 times before I beat it, but it is so rewarding when you finally do beat it. Enemies are smart, they patrol the area in groups, if they see you they will rush to the place you just were, they will shoot you through glass even you didn't see. They are very challenging but never unfair. Using weapons is a trade off, guns give you range, but attract many enemies to your area, melee weapons are completely silent, but you have to get close to an enemy to kill them. There are also many ways to complete a level given the masks and your own personal preference. These masks (you unlock them by beating missions) give you a different stat boost, such as starting with a knife, more ammo, more guns, faster running, etc. This makes the levels extremely replayable, as on one run you can run faster and rush people with a melee weapon, on another you can spam a machine gun because of the extra ammo. This gives this short adventure many more hours than originally, and I'm sure coming back to play this game in the future would be amazing. I have to also commend the art-style and the music. Good god, both of these are SUPERB, as many indie games these days tend to be. The art-style lends itself a nice cartoonish style that is simple and easy on the eyes, yet still gets everything done, and done well. The music is also extremely great and fits the style of this game very well. I recommend purchasing or downloading this soundtrack because it it so dang nice. It fits this game as well as the FTL soundtrack fits that game. The control aspect is done alright, but it was a little weird to get use to. Locking on is almost essential for guns, but it is extremely tough to lock on to an enemy that is rushing you, which can lead to some annoying deaths. I'm not sure what could be done about this though, so I guess it was done the best it could've been. Last thing, the story is also very nice, confusing and inviting questions like the Five Nights at Freddy's, but with interesting characters and characters that you don't understand at first. No spoilers, but the ending is satisfying, you will be angry at characters in the game, and you will be confused by many of them. Hands down, this game is amazing, but if you get frustrated really easily this game might not be for you.

Hotline Miami is a top-down action game/shooter made to represent the retro style of the 1980's. Complete with heart racing, fast-paced gameplay and heart pumping music, you play as an unnamed man who recieves a Rooster mask in a package and cryptic messages from his answering machine that lead him to buildings chalk-full of russian mobsters. Your goal is to clear each level of all life and return to your car as quick as you can. At first glance you'll think that this game is extremely violent, and you'd be right. But Hotline Miami does not brag about it's over-the-top violence. Holy Hell, buy this game.  Sprinting through a three-story building owned and currently occupied by the Russian mafia wearing a latex animal mask, kicking in doors, firing full-auto SMGs and emptying both barrels of a side-by-side shotgun into a mafioso wearing a cheap white suit before picking up a pot of boiling hot water and pouring it over a guy's face while bass-bumping electronic music soundtracks the entire event. Then you're presented with the question; 'Do you enjoy hurting people?' This game won my heart from the very beginning and I've easily purchased 10 copies of it to give to friends that haven't tried it yet.   Pros: -Absolutely stellar soundtrack! It themes the game perfectly, and is incredibly catchy! -Art-style fits the motif well. From the 80s color schemes to the fonts used in the cutscenes and menus to the retro arcadey-style pixelated top-down camera angle. Everything screams what this game's setting is, and does so perfectly. -Combat is quick, dirty, and punishing. You need to figure out how best to clear every room of a building loaded with bad guys, which can boil down to what rooms you clear first, what mask you pick to do the job, what weapons you use at what time, and more. The AI patterns change occasionally, making every attempt a different animal. Devolver Studios made a move that to some might not seem important, but to me made the game make-or-break, and that is the 'R' To Restart button. If I were to have to watch a cutscene every time I died, or navigate a menu or something just to restart I would have put this game down long before I finished it. Luckily, being able to hit R to restart that section of the level as soon as I saw my corpse hit the ground made all the difference. It keeps things fresh, and keeps you hooked to the computer. You keep telling yourself 'Just one more respawn, I'll get it this time' and that is a sign of the game doing a good job at keeping you enthralled.   Cons: -Story really isn't fleshed out. While I consider what we have been shown of the story to be entertaining and intriguing, there are many people, myself included, who would like to have more fleshed out about the storyline of Hotline Miami. You're left with a lot of questions about what goes on in the game at the end of it that I can only hope they will address in some manner in the second game. I've heard the critique that Hotline Miami tries too hard to maintain a '2deep4u' storyline, and honestly I can see where people get that idea given the fact that quite a bit about the storyline is purposefully kept in the shadows.  -The pixel-graphics style is beyond played out in this day and age in PC gaming. Every developer and their grandmother is attempting to make a retro-styled pixel-graphic game. That being said, Hotline Miami does it right with clear and easy to read sprites and the fact that it's not another Metroidvania Rougelike like everyone else is putting out these days.  -Story line is a bit too short for me. I have finished the game multiple times in my relatively short amount of playtime in the game. Granted, the length of your playtime is going to be based upon how many times you've died, but at the same time I finished the game jonesing for more gameplay. The game holds some replay value with a hidden puzzle to collect pieces for and the fact that it's an entertaining gameplay formula regardless of story, but I can only help but feel like another couple missions wouldn't have hurt. That might just be my addiction talking though.  All in all, this game is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ brilliant and I highly, highly recommend it. It holds a place in my heart for one of my favorite videogames of all time!

I have to let you guys know upfront that I'm really a fan of the 80s vibe. Seriously man, something about the pastel teal and pink puts the lead in my pencil. The very first time I saw Hotline Miami's menu, heard it's music, before I had even PLAYED the game, I was hooked. To my great relief, the actual game is just as dope as the aesthetic.  Gameplay in HM isn't particularly deep. You are dropped into an area and must kill every mother ♥♥♥♥er in there to advance. This is harder than it sounds: the face of death smiles on your character if an enemy so much as sneezes on him. You generally have to observe patrol patterns to formulate the most effective strategy. In my mind, I think of Hotline Miami as a puzzle game. Instead of moving blocks, you take lives in the most effecient manner possible.  The game grades you for your performance, and there are some sexy unlocks that are earned through high grades and exploration. At the start of each level, you choose which of your masks you will don. They all have a different effect of varying potency with the more powerful ones generally having to be found in their levels. You also unlock weapons and letters for a secret message (these must also be located). No spoilers, but it's in your best interest to try to locate those letters.  The story is surreal, chaotic and awesome. The game already has atmosphere in spades, the sharply written dialogue and trippy twists put it over the top. Basically, Drive: The Videogame, or at least how it looked from the Driver's perspecitve.  With everything else the game has going for it, I was surprised to find that my favorite part of the whole thing was the music. Seriously, the music in Hotline Miami is incredible. It would be incredible to listen to by yourself in a leisurely manner, but what makes it truly remarkable is how well it flows with the game. Try to play the game without music - you can't, really, truly can't. I cannot think of another game where this has been the case.  So, in closing, the game hits every bullet point. It can be frustrating, but is never dull. Occasionally shallow, but always fun. Extremely aesthetically pleasing, in both the graphics and music. A story you can sink your teeth into, and the gameplay to go along with it. Great experience for any gamer, provided they are not put off by the (extreme) 8-bit violence.  8.2/10

Hotline Miami is a fast paced top down... shooter, I guess? Personally, I played through most of the game by slamming peoples faces into doors. While there is a fairly solid plot, the game is of a fairly short length being able to be beaten in just a few hours, and most of the levels have little to no narrative. Effectively, the fun of the game comes from the fact you die if you get hit by anything. Any stray bullet or baseball bat to the face is lethal. Of course, this applies to enemies as well--with a few exceptions, mostly bosses--so combat tends to be, depending on your approach, either a puzzle, or a fast paced twitch shooter. The protagonist, Jacket, can also wear a variety of masks, gained through being found in the environment, and from progress in-game. Each mask gives a different ability, from making doors lethal, to giving you a knife to start with. The soundtrack, flashy visuals and high speed, brutal gameplay results in a consistant feeling of accomplishment for getting through every--fairly difficult--encounter. Failing is fast, and it only takes seconds to get back into the action. This is a game for speedrunners, and for people who like fast paced, intense action, along with rewarding, brutal, combat. Or for people who like to puzzle through things through trial and error.   The combat, general gameplay, music, and plot makes for a very enjoyable experience, and it's definitely a recommended buy if you like this sort of game. However, while the plot is servicable, and well executed, it's not stellar and not worth buying the game over.

Addictive and fast-paced gameplay with little, if any, penalty in progress on each death.  Before purchasing Hotline Miami, I recommend giving the soundtrack a listen. You'll be hearing it a lot and while I really like it, it might not be for everyone.  While the visceral top-down combat may be what the game is notorious for, the storyline is a nice addition and I appreciate the clever use of metaphor as an examination of types of player over a narrative that attempts to show us a world we don't need to understand, instead making the world a forum for debate through exposition and actions commited. The game itself can be a little trial and error based at times and isn't entirely free from bugs but it can be really fun regardless.  Do bear in mind however that the game offers fun gameplay but very little in replay value unless you're absolutely set on beating highscores on the same levels over and over. It would've benefitted greatly from the addition of a Steam Workshop integrated Level Editor. Even if it isn't that 'kind' of game. Maybe in the sequel we'll see something like that.  The bottom line is, essentially, if you're looking for a game you can waste time with for a while, Hotline Miami could be it. But don't expect it to last too long.

This in turn allows you to unlock additional melee weapons and firearms, which then have a chance of spawning randomly in future levels (either on the floor of a room or in the hands of an enemy). I can't say I normally challenge myself particularly with video games, but because of the ease with which you are killed in Hotline Miami I found it exhilarating to burst through doors and hope I had taken the enemy by surprise.  The old school graphics are really awesome, and with the top-down style the visuals in Hotline Miami make me think of a cleaner-looking GTA. Hotline Miami is a top-down shooter where you murder everybody you see. You require nothing more than an answering machine message and an address to butcher each and every soul within the game's pixelated, 2D walls. But you're never given a reason for your psychotic actions--the focus is on the joy of murder, and though Hotline Miami can be frustrating at times, its frantic gameplay and slick presentation make for some gloriously satisfying bloodshed.   The game opens with the nameless protagonist standing in a room. And, mysteriously, there are three men wearing animal masks making cryptic comments about your identity and actions. Is this real, or some drug-induced fever dream? You're not given much time to contemplate it. The screen fades to black, and you awake in a filthy apartment in April 1989. A bloodstained shirt lies in the hall as an answering machine light blinks on and off. This is the setup for most of the 19 chapters that make up Hotline Miami. A short message asks you to 'clean up' or 'visit' a certain address, which is followed by a trip to a building full of supposed criminals that you must slaughter floor by floor.

What is Hotline Miami? What does it do that captivates players? Is it the fast-paced action? Is it the violence? Perhaps, it's the music and 80s vibes. What presents Hotline Miami as such a special and visceral experience?    The game starts off in an apartment, located in an 80s Miami. You control an unidentifiable person (he stays anonymous throughout the entire experience). He receives an abrupt phone call from a number that goes under “Tim's Bakery”, but is implied to be a hitman service. The player is told to open up the box of “cookies” and an “ingredient” list, on the nearby doorstep. Rather, the character finds a rooster mask and a list of information on a certain target. You are instructed to take the target out, extract his briefcase, and rid it in an alleyway dumpster. After going to the location, beating faces to a pulp, ridding the briefcase, and ending another life, the main character bends over and profusely vomits. This shows that he's disgusted with what he's done. This moment defines where Hotline Miami truly takes initiative with its story.     As our once-innocent denizen eats away at Miami's population of crackheads, he starts to relish it. Ideally, this is shown through the gameplay and subtle progression of the main character. He learns new styles of killing, takes on bigger amounts of mobsters, and evolves into a complete psychopath. You see the damage you've done and the lives you've taken, as a blood-soaked protagonist walks back out of every area he's obliterated. It really provides for an effective atmosphere and unsettling set of emotions. That's just a prime example of what makes Hotline Miami so powerful.     Each style is earned through receiving new masks by level completions, high scores, and achievements. There are a variety of mask styles to choose from, and they truly tip the re-playability scale. For example, you could choose the “Brandon (panther)” mask. This mask makes the character run faster. Players could also use the “Zack (frog)” mask, which allows for a larger combo window. As killing goes, there are different ways to go about taking down your targets. One can go in guns blazing. Or, they could take a slower, melee-based attempt. The levels are designed for players to take multiple, different attempts in each playthrough. As they progress through this game with discomforting repletion, they will soon realize how short it actually is. This twisted Miami tale could be described best as a one-day visit to a favorite theme park.    Through pulsing, bass-hitting beats, this game ensures that you'll be killing in style. From synthwave rings to dark electronic throttles, one will be consumed by the soundtrack's flaring and bold atmosphere. M.O.O.N, Perturbator, Scattle, and Jasper Byrne are a few artists involved with providing this. The soundtrack is truly one of HM's strong suits.    The genius story telling, the brutality, the gore, the neon-soaked 80s aesthetic, the atmosphere, the subtle implications of the main character, and the soundtrack make Hotline Miami art. Some say games cannot be art. In my eyes, they truly can. This indie game takes a brutal and shocking concept, and does it in a surprisingly un-edgy way. We take control of a character that has everything stripped away from him, as he's brainwashed into killing everything in sight. As he's subjected to the gruesome nature, he begins to adjust to it. The tailoring of the human mind is expressed in his story, and the game should be appreciated for what it presents. Hotline Miami is a special gaming experience that every gamer should try.  8.5/10   TL;DR Get the damn game.

This game is a gem of a top-down, 2D action game. A bloody, gore-covered, fast-paced, action-filled gem. You take control of the 'protagonist' named 'Jacket', as he responds to otherwise mundane tasks given to him by anonymous callers by going to the given address and murdering the life out of everyone while wearing an animal-themed rubber mask. Oh, and he has episodes where he's mentally accosted by what we can only assume are his spirit animals.  The old-school art style suits the game well, as does the music. Everything seems appropriately trippy, given Jacket's psyche and mental condition. There's a lot of blood and violence involved, so if you're squeamish about literally pixelfulls of blood, bones and brain littered about your screen, then bully for you.  Stages usually consist of a building full of baddies for you to viciously murder, which is then divided by floors/areas. Transitioning from floor to floor also serves as much-needed checkpoints. Stages are completed when all enemies have been thorughly disassembled. At the end of each stage, a score is calculated based on your performance, which in turn is based on time taken to complete the stage, combo kills, etc. etc. Higher scores means faster weapon unlocks and validation for your l33t skillz.  Most enemies you encounter will be of the bald, white-coat-wearing, squishy and esily killable variety. Later on, dogs, rotund, stripe-coated gangsters and SWAT guys will enter the fray. Boss fights are also going to happen. Deal with it.  You have a vast arsenal of weaponry at your disposal to aid you in your murderous rampage, ranging from mundane frying pans and pool cues to assault rifles and shotguns. Fisticuffs are an option as well, however a solid punch will only ever temporarily knock down an enemy, requiring you to perform an execution to finish the sucker off.   Melee weapons usually get the job done in one good hit, and vary in terms of swing/attack speed and effective range. They can also be thrown at enemies with varying degrees of effectiveness, depending on your aim and type of weapon thrown: most thrown melee weapoins will knock enemies down, while bladed weapons like knives and shuriken can kill. Pick these goodies up from fallen foes.  Ranged weapons are obviously great at taking foes out from a distance, and differ in terms of damage done per bullet, bullet spread type, accuracy, ammo capacity and noisiness. Guns make a lot of noise, often attracting the attention of other enemies and making them rush you, which can quickly put you in a bad spot if you run out of ammo. Again, these can be collected from the corpses of slain baddies.  Masks can be collected along the way, allowing you to accessorize to your heart's content before heading in for a night of killing. Each mask offers different and not-insubstantial perks that might suit your play style, so choose wisely to avoid a possible fashion faux pas.  Your environment isn't just for show, either. Take advantage of your surroundings by luring enemies into narrow corridors and mowing them down with gunfire, or waiting for them to walk by the corner where you eagerly await with your meat cleaver held high. Doors are a godsend, and will quickly become your enemies' worst nightmare, as you gleefully slam doors into their faces and laugh as they sprawl on the ground before murderizing them.   Make no mistake, Hotline Miami is pretty damn difficult. You will die often, most of the time in a manner that would have you cussing and cursing at your monitor like a sailor who's terrible at video games. The difficulty ramps up nicely as the game progresses, oftentimes courting the line between stupidly hard and downright unreasonable.  A lot of trial and error is involved, as the AI can be frustratingly inconsistent. It is very difficult to accurately predict how enemies will move or react (ex. enemies doing nothing while you take out enemies standing right beside them VS gun-wielding enemies instantly turning around and blasting you to hell as you stalk past them), forcing you to adapt your chosen strategy as you go, or, when you've died enough times, make you resort to bashing the movement keys and the attack button, mentally broadcasting pleas for success to your preferred deity. Getting killed means that you have to start the floor all over again, an experience which is exactly as soul-crushing as it sounds.  This, however, doesn't mean that the game isn't good. Keyboard and mouse controls work wonderfully, and the game's mechanics are sound enough that you won't get killed unfairly at the hands of anything other than the sometimes questionable AI. There is a palpable and genuine sense of accomplishment when you complete a level, and the story is genuinely interesting, if mildly obscure.  Bottomline: if you dont mind pixel ultra-violence and are looking for a challenge, get this game. FIN

Really great game. It follows a really cool 80's style with gory fast-paced gameplay, along with a decent storyline. The game is a lot of fun, and I've really done all you can do here, so I'll be a better guide for whether to buy this game or not.   First off, this game has some really fun gameplay. It focuses on a ranking system, where you unlock masks that give little bonuses and special weapons you can find spawn in missions. These masks give some replayablity since getting every single one gets hard to do and each has their own fun strategy. Other than that, it gives a really fast paced game where all you have to do is clear each room. It sounds simple, and it is, but it's all about learning the timing and the best way to kill each enemy, and becomes pretty easy to beat each level once you learn the idea of how to beat it. Now, I think that actually also adds replayability because the 'hard' games like Dark Souls has it to where it's always hard, and it's less about getting the timing right and more about learning how to fight, which is just improved as you play the game, and no matter what any point in the game will be managable once you learn it, instead of constantly learning in the 'hard' Hotline Miami and putting it into play later on a second playthrough. The story is pretty good, but there isn't much to say about it. After you start playing the game a second time, you start to search for all masks, and in the process, collecting all of the letters in the levels (collectables). The really cool thing about this is that when you complete the game a first time, you don't really know what happened and what's going on, and why it happened; when you collect all of these letters and find out a secret code you figure out the game's world and everything there is to know, and it's really satisfying.  This game is just made well, and you can see it. Everything feels really exciting and you actually sometimes can get scared, or amused, or angry, and it feels good. No matter what you experience, there is always a sense of acomplishment once you finish the fair levels, and it's really nice. It makes you want to play more until there is no more missions, and it doesn't stop there, like I said before. The replayability in this game is a good relief since the story can be beaten in like 8 hours, and beating it again takes like 6 hours if you go for completionist second playthough. I am really glad I have these hours and so are most people, and it's really an experience everyone should get to feel.

Has a lot of blood and guns, 10/10.  But seriously. I bought this game because I came across some spare change while cleaning my room. Little did I know that for the rest of that week I would finish the game and spend countless hours getting each and every little achievement hidden in this masterpiece. The replayability of Hotline Miami is incredible, especially for a game developed by only two guys. The gameplay may seem a bit samey at first, but the more you play it, the more you start to develop your own little strategies. Never once did I need to consult the internet about a part where I didn't know what to do or how to do it. This is one of the game's strongest points. The premise is very simple: kill all Russians. This allows for very steamlined and fast-paced gameplay. You know what to do, you know how to do it, now do it. Not that this game is easy. On the contrary, getting a perfect score on each stage was one of the hardest gaming experiences I've had to date. The music is also brilliant. It fits the gameplay very well. Tracks like Hydrogen and Perturbator in particular really steal the show in this regard. This is in my opinion one of the only games that really deserves to have its own OST for sale on Steam. This is honestly my favourite game I've played this year, and I'm really looking forward to Hotline Miami 2.

Hotline Miami is a top down indie arcade game developed by Dennaton Games and published by Devolver Digital. This is the first game developed by the three man team at Dennaton but Devolver Digital are well known for bringing classic legends like Duke Nukem 3D and Shadow Warrior to the modern market. The fact that they’re publishing Hotline Miami is a fairly big deal and hopefully it will add to the reasons why people should love this game.  You play as a hitman for a Russian mob in Miami Florida in 1989. Not much is revealed at the start, but as the game progresses you start to uncover more about the story. I don’t want to spoil anything, but there are a few twists and turns that will keep your interest. The story is basic, but it’s riddled with mystery, tragedy, betrayal, and questions upon questions upon questions.  So in terms of gameplay, everything is played from a top down perspective. The controls are fairly basic, moving around with WASD and aiming with the mouse. Each level requires you to kill all enemies before proceeding to the next area and doing the same thing. Once all enemies are dead, you win. What keeps the game varied is the vast amount of weapons you can use and the random drops they have on each level. You also get a large selection of masks to choose from at the start of each mission. Each of these masks has a different perk such as quiet gunshots or starting the level with a knife. As you complete levels you unlock more masks but there are also hidden collectibles (including a few super secret masks) to find.  The game is very difficult. Enemy AI is very responsive and it just takes one gunshot/melee attack to kill you and force you to start the level again. As I was playing, I found myself doing the same parts over and over trying to complete it. There are different tactics you can use and getting to choose a mask can sometimes make things much easier, but prepare yourself for a real challenge.  The soundtrack to Hotline Miami is incredible. I absolutely loved the original score composed by several different well known artists such as Jasper Byrne, M.O.O.N., and Perturbator. It really works with the reckless violent gameplay, and kept me playing the game even when I felt like throwing my computer out the window.   Length wise, I completed the main story in about 3 hours. A few parts gave me hell so it might take a more experienced player 2 hours or less. There is an epilogue story that adds a few more levels onto the main story, but don’t expect to spend more than 5 hours to finish. Despite this short amount of time, there is a lot of replayability. Collecting all the collectibles and masks will take some time and trying to get the best possible score for each level is a good challenge. There are also several achievements that will help keep you occupied while replaying parts of the game. I estimate someone interested in this game could get 8-10 hours in total, but the gameplay is so addictive that many people will probably replay the game just for the experience.  Hotline Miami is a great indie gem that in my opinion, no one should miss. It’s fairly priced for what you’re getting and definitely not something that the average gamer will forget playing.   My final verdict is 88/100. I wanted a longer story with perhaps a few more enemy types, but apart from those things, I really enjoyed everything about the game!

Your mission: Get in, kill all the bad guys and get out. Use whatever weapon you can take from the bad guys or find on the ground: Beat up that guy, take his knife and then slit his throat. Throw it at the next guy, pick up his Shotgun and make some noise before picking up that Katana from the ground and waiting behind the door...  Really fun and addictive top down shooter with lots of blood and gore. It has that Super Meat Boy feel to it where you die in the first few seconds, hit the restart button and then die again... By getting good scores you unlock more weapons aswell as new masks that give a bonus during a level, like running faster or being able to tank more damage.   The music is really awesome and gets you pumped up, just in the right mood to plow through a room of baddys. The overall feel of the story, delivered in very short dialogues between missions is pretty cool. It goes from a relatively happy, carefree world into a bad one where suddenly you see corpses everywhere. It's quite effective given how short the sequences are.  Speaking of short... The biggest downside is the length: I beat the main story in 2 hours and another hour for the bonus story. I'm guessing that finding every single puzzle piece in each level unlocks another story sequence, but all in all the game remains very short.   Pick this up when it's on sale and enjoy some bloody action~

'Are Video Games Art?'  All of us have at one point heard, been asked, or have asked, this very question. In the vast majority if cases, I would say that Video Games are not Art. But Hotline Miami has changed that for me.   Hotline Miami blends colour with music like no other game I have ever played. Its harsh, rapid beat mixed with the pschycadellic Imagery immerses one fully into the Miami Underworld of the 1980s. The Gameplay, although frustrating, works extremely well and the graphics prove that even pixelated games can be beautiful and powerful. The Story is convoluted and complex, and without understanding what exactly was going on, I enjoyed the well-paced plot and interesting dialogue nonetheless.    Is it frustrating, and rage-enducing? Yes. But it is also a game that, no matter how often I complete, I always come back to, ready for another Trip to Miami.  All in all, Hotline Miami remains a fantastic experience that I am glad to have experienced. But dont let me need to tell you. Buy the game and let the sensation you will feel decide.  9/10.

So, do you like hurting other people? This is the game for you then. (If you're one of those politically correct wusses then please feel free to drop the soap of comformity as you would normally)  Hotline Miami is a top down shooter or 'f*ck 'em up' as some describe, caked in gore with wet little bits of meat all over the place. Set in 1980s Miami you, a nameless hitman receiving strange anonymous calls on your answering machine must eliminate everyone you come across, oh and you have one life to do it in otherwise, 'Press R to restart' just as an enemy whacks your head in with a lead pipe.   The gameplay is quite challenging to anyone new but you get into the swing of things early on in game, hell even I  beat the game in under an hour , the difficulty of the game can be off putting at first but once you get used to it, cutting someone into neat little pieces with a katana is a great stress reliever and arguably gets easier the more times you do (don't try this one at home kids). On a side note, going in guns blazing is exactly what the game was designed for so don't be all stingy with your ammo except when you're faced with the fat black dudes.  The story is immidiately reminiscent of Tarantino movies, in the sense that they're someone going to die soon and violently but that's where the similarities end, it is ambiguous to the greater extent whether this is all just one big acid trip, in a coma or you're just plain mad. Ultimately not having all the answers adds to the game's trippy feel since the final secret ending lacks a bit.  The sound and visuals tie in together beautifully as the soundtrack is one of the finest ever made, the rhythm of the neo 80s tunes are perfectly in sync with your massacring which, although is presented 8-bit style, your mind just fills in what the graphics don't detail enough for you, besides adding a bit of character to the game as well. The rooms you're in also appear to wobble with constantly changing warm colours that melt away in the background, it makes you wonder just what on Earth you're character's been eating.  All in all, the violence, the acidic visuals, indescribably good soundtrack and mysterious story create a trip unlike any you've been on before or ever again after. Until the sequel came along that is. One small criticism was that this game ends way too quickly for the moderately skilled like me.

Dennaton Games released this little indie gem in 2012. Hyper-violence through pixel art, this game puts players in the role of a nameless anti-hero who receives strange phone calls directing him to commit unspeakable acts of graphic violence. Set in 1989 Miami, the techno soundtrack thumps away in a monotonous throbbing pulse as a perfect soundtrack to the extreme violence and chaos. The colours are all hypnotic 80's vibrant fluro reds, pinks and greens and fit with the time period perfectly. There's a real sense of uneasiness about this game as you converse with faceless people in pig and horse masks, asking you questions like, 'Do you enjoy hurting people?'. The games difficultly harkens back to the old days of brutally hard Sega and Nes titles where one hit means you're dead, that's it, start the level again. There's an achievement for dying 1,000 times, I hit it at just over 5 hours (mind you I also hit the achievement around the same time for killing 1989 enemies so it's balanced out). The graphics are delightfully retro pixel art that beautifully complements the disturbing nature of the games themes. Proof that you don't need big budgets and high end processing power to deliver a truly enjoyable and thought provoking gaming experience.

One of my favorite kind of games is the kind that knows exactly what it wants to be. From there, every component of the game, from graphics to music and gameplay can then be crafted to create a greater, more unified whole. I think that this is one of the ways that you can make a truly great game.  'Hotline Miami' succeeds in this way in an astounding fashion. It is a frenetic fever dream, combining twitch gameplay with tight level design, fitting aesthetics, and a killer soundtrack. 'Hotline' does particularly well with atmosphere, creating an immersive and bloody acid trip. It's easy to lose oneself in the hypnotic beats and waves of psychedelia that surround this game.  To be fair, 'Hotline' isn't a game for everyone. It is difficult and can be frustrating. The player can sometimes die from bullets fired from off-screen or by running into the same bad scenario again and again until they solve it. But it's for these reasons that 'Hotline' also succeeds, much for the same reasons that 'Super Meat Boy' did. Despite its difficulty, the punishment for failure is rather small. The player respawns almost instantly, giving them a second, third, or hundredth chance at murder.   My first playthrough of 'Hotline Miami' shortly after its original release was one of my most refreshing experiences in gaming. I can't recommend that everyone should play this game enough, even if it's only to see what happens when you don't try to do too much and instead focus on what makes your game excellent.

If you can't tell when a game has FPS way below the refresh of a decent monitor and aren't bothered by control issues, the game might be for you, if you are bothered by those, I'd only recommend the game, if you have a saint-like frustration tolerance.  the good: - interesting, trippy 'story' - imaginative, visceral kill animations - kinda skillbased combat mechanics - satisfying feeling when you get better and do cooler stuff - good replay-value - price below 1€/$/£ when in sale - no lading times after each numerous death - interesting violence-based humour - many masks/weapons to unlock, not too grind-heavy - amazing soundtrack, good sound effects  the bad: - very random enemy AI. Sometimes they see and shoot you while being far out of your max vision reach. Othertimes they stand next to you and do nothing.  - special 'stealth mission with no killing' is very annoying - some enemies are magically invulnerable to certain attacks - w/o any explanation - can't save mid-mission; so it's easy to lose 10+ minutes of gameplay if you have to leave  the ugly: - FPS lock - mousecursor is virtually invisible with all the trippy colors and stuff going on - terrible controls. not only because you can't rebind keys, but the character moves as he's on ice, sliding and not being very precise. - same silly, semi-unskippable cutscene plays in certain levels. This game is an acid trip with a touch of violence.  Hotline Miami brings a unique top down 'dual stick' shooter and beat em up to a whole new level. There are a variety of weapons at your disposal as well as masks the player can choose at the start of each level- These can either buff or handicap you, so you have to change up your playstyle depending on which one you choose to don.   You can choose to be sneaky and take out the baddies one at a time, but the game rewards you with recklessness. To get a high score and rating; you must chain together combos, and use different weapons every so often.  YOU WILL DIE A LOT in this game but it's as easy as pressing 'R' each time and the game immediately puts you at the beginning. No loadtimes after death so you can jump right back into the action and change up your strategies.  Now to the music, well... it's amazing, it pumps you up and is a mash up of dance and electronic music. Along with the trippy visuals the music ties in well with the game.  The Story is not uniform but random and obscure, it makes the game interesting. Each chapter has multiple stages and they always begin with the protagonist in his apartment, reading a message on his answering machine about the mission, and him driving to the stage.   I recommend this game, it has a lot of secrets and unlocks so there is replay value, and to my knowledge this is the only game that has this kind of flare.

“Follow protocol and we’ll all make it out alive,” says a boss character in one of Hotline Miami’s later missions. It’s a perfectly reasonable thing for him to say to his henchmen. All who hear him probably think it’s good advice, wisdom dispensed to survive an impending attack by you, a relentless killer. So they follow orders and do what they’ve been trained to do. Some stand with guns, some patrol rooms with knives, and all are ready to slash and shoot and murder the intruder in a bloody font of insta-death. Yet none who heard the order appreciate its irony. They don’t comprehend that by following protocol they follow the game rules that you've learned to overcome, and that by complying with their boss set themselves up to have their brains splattered against the wall and organs spilled across the floor.  Dennaton Games’ Hotline Miami is stuffed with moments like this that stir up identity and purpose into a neon-lashed, ultraviolent, self-aware skewering of video game conventions and the nature of entertainment. Lynchian scenes of surrealist intrigue pop up right at the very beginning as masked figures ridicule you about events they never explain, immediately and succinctly establishing a sense of distrust. The nonstop flux of pinks and purples wrapped around the edges of every playable area, the grainy waves washing across the retro visuals and sublime soundtrack where reverb bleeds from fat synths over electronic beats aren’t solely for style, but mesh perfectly with the sense of worming paranoia established through the dialogue, amplifying Hotline Miami’s lonely, dreamlike qualities, where nothing is necessarily certain aside from the promise of a gore-splattered spectacle when a stage is complete. To compound this sense of distrust, every mission is based on a lie; a phone message asking you to kill for false reasons. There are a few explorable non-combat spaces and each feels like a tease. You have an apartment with an old video game console on the ground. You pick up pizza boxes and VHS tapes and eventually gain a roommate and you can never interact with any of them in a significant way. They are all background elements. They are initially framed as non-essential. The only way to truly interact with the world is to kill. Such is the case with many games, yet few call out the inanity of it so bluntly.  Before a mission begins you put on a mask. Each confers gameplay bonuses and further obfuscates your identity to place emphasis on what you do, not who you are. The overhead perspective serves a similar dual purpose. It enables you to look across vast stretches of each playable area where enemies wait behind doors and breakable windows to kill you in a fraction of a second. The perspective allows you to plan how to move, from which angle to fire a shotgun or toss a knife or stun an enemy by opening a door behind him just as he passes then proceed to wreck his face against the floor. The perspective also dehumanizes your targets by presenting them as only heads and shoulders and weapons, an effect strengthened by their pixelated appearance. It’s not until they’re dead and their bodies sprawl across the ground in full view with blood pooling about them that they feel human and, maybe for a moment, you feel a twitch of remorse.  Yet whatever regret you may have over brutally and relentlessly murdering is immediately neutered as Hotline Miami flashes a giant score bonus over each fresh corpse. Kill multiple people quickly and you’ll build combos. With enough speed and efficiency and recklessness you’ll amass higher scores and unlock more masks and weapons and receive better ratings at each mission’s end. The gameplay is kind of stealth but mostly quick action. You wait around hallway corners for an enemy to walk away then sprint around the corner with a crowbar, break his head, toss the crowbar at the shotgun-carrying enemy in the room’s corner to score a stun, throat rip the guy who just wandered in then pounce on the still-stunned foe to punctuate the spree with a burst of gore, and in those moments of blood-soaked success feel a rush of satisfaction because it could have gone so horribly wrong. Hotline Miami doesn’t only share the same audio-visual themes of Nicolas Winding Refn’s Drive (the director is specifically thanked in the credits), but also the same kind of startling ease of transition between life and death. In general, if you get hit, you die, and if you hit an enemy, they die. The game auto-saves after you change floors of the buildings you assault, but each floor needs to be cleared without making a mistake. Resetting is quick and encouraged, much in the same way as Trials HD or Super Hexagon. Mess up and you can instantly return to the action armed with more knowledge of enemy positions and map layout. Even after you learn everything about a stage, when you respawn enemies may move in a slightly different way and they may not carry the same weapons, so memorization alone won’t result in success. There’s always an element of chaos in the action that parallels the puzzling tendrils of the story. Stringing together a continuous combo throughout a stage often requires frantic improvisation and prevents the action from suffering from too much predictability.  More depth is added through the way Dennaton handles sound. Bats and crowbars are quiet, but guns draw attention. You could run into a room and try to cut everything apart with a shotgun, but in a populated stage it’ll bring in others, some of whom may flatten you before they’re even visible with an unavoidable burst of bullets. To get around this you can target an enemy before entering a room, you can silently fling your weapon to temporarily knock him out, which may give you enough time to punch a patrolling enemy, steal his weapon and murder them both without alerting anyone else. Getting better at effectively juggling these variables, managing sound and line of sight and speed, is a rapid, noticeable process, and the sense of reward for efficiently cutting down all lethal threats is significant because there’s room to slay with custom style. As the body count rises, the sense of disconnection with the tragedy of what’s happening onscreen grows. You crave more kills to again feel that rush of just barely surviving and seeing those big, flashy numbers burst across the screen with Peggle-like splendor. You begin to think more and more like the serial killer you’re playing and find delight in the purity of the task, not the implications. Yet for all the ways Hotline Miami seems to needlessly pop skulls and spray blood, it does so for a reason.  It’s hinted throughout the early non-combat scenes that bookend missions that at first seem so disposable. Violence begins to infect what initially seems to be a wearying, comically dull routine where you run errands following a successful killing spree. Even as the world around you is corrupted by the grotesque and shop owners carry on disturbingly reasonable conversations with corpses bleeding at their feet, you don’t react. You proceed as usual, mission to mission, a process suggestive of a far deeper and troubling psychosis, again thickening the layers of dishonesty in Hotline Miami’s presentation and strengthening its motivating sense of intrigue. Direct and implied lies are piled up until fantasy and reality are inextricably bound, and Dennaton finds ingenious ways of integrating interactivity and story development to keep you directly involved in the process. While the characters rattle the bars of their virtual prisons, driven to discover some kind of truth under the apparent pointlessness of their missions, Hotline Miami’s hyperactive pacing never slackens as it continually offers the same solutions to all the existential issues raised: keep killing, keep playing.

Mindblowingly addictive. Often frustrating. Always groovy. If you've pondered the possibilities of your ability to slowly impale a man with a pool cue you just broke over his friend's skull, gouge out a fellow's eyes with a throwing dart, or simultaneously kill 3 firearm toting thugs with a single heartily thrown brick, then you've come to the right place!  At first glance, I figured Hotline Miami would be an okay little top-down distraction at a cheap price tag; I was quickly proven wrong. The gameplay is fast-paced and if for any reason it isn't, then you are doing it wrong. It is one of those games where you repeatedly start a level and die in the same way over and over until your mind is numb... and it is awesome! What really makes this game is the soundtrack; a lot of my time was spent anticipating the next level to see if it came along with a new and awesome sounding '80s electronica tune. The story's presentation isn't anything amazing; it is actually somewhat repetitive - get a call, go kill some guys, go to a shop, go home and repeat. This isn't represenative of the plot though! The plot is a bit of a vague cluster-f**k and will likely have you on a wiki page trying to decrypt exactly what in the hell was going on. Along with all this, replay value is present because of the secret ending, achievements, and just plain fun!

Where some games appeal to the brain or heart this game seeks only your adrenal gland. Each map presents the player with a bright and engaging enviromental canvas to paint with the nigh neon color of criminal blood. This game is as brutal as it is bright, nearly every thing can kill you as easily as you can kill it. The array of masks can add to slow your near constant death cycle out increase challenge adding a layer of depth to the normally straight forward combat.  Speaking of, combat as mentioned above is fairly simple to grasp Kill or Be Killed. While most weapons are obvious: Guns and Pipes, sometimes you might find something surprising to lodge into the skull of the men unlucky enough to round a corner you're behind. Though I would be doing a misservice if I didn't mention that sometimes you die needlessly due to an excess of windows or an enemy, who had only been knocked down during a frenzied spray of bullets, bury his pipe in the back of your head. One other complaint being that on occasion the 'predictable' enemies seemed to either be too dumb for their own good or suddenly gain the reaction time of Spider-man, though this sort of thing didn't happen enough to become more then a momentary annoyance   The story may not appeal to every one, it is rather then but provides all the motivation one needs to sprint about in a fury to get that one last kill for a combo. However, the story has its moments where it is a flawlass descent in to a bloody hysteria.   I chose this game to recommend for the interesting story, tight gameplay, but most of all because of its grim and brutal combat contrasted with a world alight with neon.

I was first introduced to this game through an online shooter that I often play, Payday 2. And so, I decided to buy this game and give it a try. It is an ultra-violent, Clockwork Orange-type 8-Bit top-down shooter and I must say I've never had anything quite like this. First off, I want to say that this games' atmosphere and soundtrack are un-believable. Absolutely ridiculous. The game is based around the 80s in Miami, at the height of the neon scene, and thumping club hits accompany you as you mow down waves of white-suited Russian mobsters. This game is incredibly addicting, particularly because one mistake, one single slip-up, and you die and have to start the level all over again. At least for me, this spurred me to persevere until I emerged victorious from the blood-soaked halls of a Mafiya apartment. Also, the story is quite interesting, particularly when the game begins to question the players' notions about that is real and what isn't. On the whole, I had no idea what awaited me when I shelled out the 15$ for this game its' soundtrack, and I am still enthralled by this game's disco soundtrack juxtaposed with the unending violence that occurs on Miami's dark streets. Dennaton has a masterpiece on their hands. Overall Score: 9.6/10

Hotline Miami is a top down gorefest that takes place in the Miami of 1989. You play as a nameless murderer who wears animal masks and recieves calls on his message machine telling him what buildings to clear out.  Much like the Hitman games, you are scored and given a title for how you go about clearing each level. However, in almost exact opposition to Hitman, your score and title get better the more wreckless, gruesome, variated, and quickly your kills are performed; fear not though, instantainious respawn keeps the frustraition of dying A LOT attempting this playstyle at bay. You can still play through however you feel, but playing Silent Assassin style will cause your score to suffer. Each mask you unlock can be worn to recieve different abilities or starting items that can make the level easier or harder to play through.  The keyboard and mouse controls, while good enough to 100% the game, can be very frustraiting when things start to happen very quickly. This is because you use the mouse to aim around the room, and at high resolutions, that mouse pointer moves just a little too slow. It is because of this that I recommend using a controller as using two sticks to move and aim just makes the experience more enjoyable and less frustraiting.  The soundtrack is so good that I've added it to my setlist. The game has won two awards for its sound and audio, along with several more for its overall gameplay and design.  I strongly recommend this game to anyone who likes senseless violence, and games as artwork.

The CAG member 'RollingSkull' said it best when he called Hotline Miami a 'murder simulator'. Heaps of praise have been given to Hotline Miami and in my opinion it is justified. This is a bizarre, violent acid trip of a game with some of the most strangely satisfying combat I've played in any game. Fast twitch reflexes with equal amounts of luck will either get you through the level or pressing 'R for Restart' once again. Yes, you will get acquainted very well with the 'R' button because you will die and die A LOT. But I never really got frustrated. The gameplay is so fast and furious that you just....accept it and try out a different plan. Ahh, the plan. There are numerous ways to try and get through each floor thanks to the variety of weapons and effects from the different masks you can try on. Some good (Peter the Unicorn), some bad (Nigel the Bat). This is the best, most addicting game I've played this year. I played through the whole thing twice just to get all of the puzzle pieces so I could see the alternate ending. Don't let the ugly graphics fool you. They are perfect for this game. Oh, and let me give a shout out to the soundtrack. Normally I could not care less about the music in a game. Not this time. This is the best soundtrack I've heard in a game by a mile. Overall a highly recommended game. You WILL get your $9.99 (or less) worth.

It seems in a world of call of duties, a game like Hotline Miami might be shoved to one side and forgotten about. But that assumption would be incorrect with its favourable reviews from the gaming community as proof. And playing through the game, one would find it hard to argue that the game hasn't earned its success.  Its 1980's Miami, with a truly retro feel to match, yet things from it could be applied to the future. The AI, despite not being the most intelligent to appear on a computer screen (the predictablility of your enemies is one of your only advantages in this game), is surprisingly unforgiving and will make sure that you pay for any mishaps or slips along the way through. Thats a trait games of the modern day seem to undermine. Challenge is a necessary element for a game that pits you in situations that don't favor you. The game would lose some of its appeal to me if I didn't find myself swearing and smashing my fist on my desk from time to time.   The combat and visuals are unique to the game. As mentioned previously, the game has a very retro look to it and this has been added to a combat system which is brutal and vivid. I think what makes this game exceptional is that like a lot of games it meets the blood lust of the modern day gamer but has a plot that at the very same time questions your excessive violent actions.   With its style, intelligences, and unlockables, Hotline Miami gets a solid 8/10 only falling short on minor details like the slightly tiresome stealth section in the hospital and errors her and there. Other than that, Hotline Miami is a game to be encouraged and a game to be commended.

An excellent indie game that's well worth the money. If you don't like hard games then you might want to steer clear, but even as a very difficult game there is plenty to enjoy. The difficulty can be both punishing and forgiving, as you die in one hit, but thankfully the game only restarts you back to the start of the area. The gameplay is fast-paced and suspenseful, keeping you on your toes for the whole game as you attempt to take out all the bad guys in one area without taking a hit. The game forces you to implement some strategy and stealth into the action, making an excellently balanced blend of fun which is surprisingly addictive as you try over and over again to pass the area.  The setting and story also help the game immensely. The Miami setting gives the game a great colour palette to work with, and makes the top-down world look vibrant and safe, a contrast to the actual gameplay. And the story....it's confusing, but done so well as to make you guess what is going on, and allows you to speculate on several things, like the guy who appears in every store you go to after each level, and acts oblivious to the fact. But you know there's something to him.  All in all, Hotline Miami is well worth the $10 pricetag, and you should definitely get it when it's on sale, even if you aren't interested.
