Killroy's Quick Review: 9/10  At its core, Hotline Miami is a retro-style puzzle game that breathes life into the top-down perspective. The playstyle in which the player completes these puzzles is something unique to the fact that players must blend mobility, attention to detail, and quick reflexes to survive. The story is driven by text-based classic dialog sequences that gives an interesting look into the game's protagonist while offering up some dark laughs on the side.   Hotline Miami's asking price is more than fair considering the amount of content the purchaser receives. There are several progressively challenging chapters, a slew of unlockable passive skills and weapons that augment player choice. The chapters in Hotline Miami also offer interesting randomization to flesh out replayability further.  Aesthetically, Devolver Games presents Hotline Miami with an 8-bit engine. In the realm of audio however, Hotline Miami is supplemented with an up-beat and fitting electronic soundtrack that would attract more than just gamers, but fans of electronic music as well.  Overall, Hotline Miami hits several addictive marks that will keep the player entertained for hours. The gameplay is generally simplistic, but requires skill and strategy beyond what the gamer may first realize. The randomness presented in levels and forced key-bindings of the controls may present some initial frustrations until the player becomes familiar however. Hotline also possesses some occasional oddities such as: Weapons flying out of reach and some wonky slowdown. These oddities never reared any issues that detracted from the overall package for myself personally. In summary: Hotline Miami is a brave and unique product that will provide several hours of quality entertainment while offering a unique player experience.

Viscerally intense and yet soothingly hypnotic.   At its core Hotline Miami is very simple, yet how it goes about showcasing this to the player is wonderfully unique. Its arena shooter/brawler gameplay scores the perfect balance between weighty and yet lightning fast. Just as swift as you dole out wanton carnage, your life can end just as quick by a stray bullet. You'll rapidly find yourself in a trance replaying missions dozens of times over (never a tire thanks to the instant reset), slowly working towards achieveing the perfect killing spree. Combine that with an open-ended storyline that never steps too far out of bounds (pretentious indie games should take note), vibrantly gruesome pixel art, and a thumping electronic soundtrack and you got yourself a near-perfect indie hit!   All that's left for Dennaton Games is to iron out the bugs that occasionally pester an otherwise outstanding game.

It's hard to stand out from the crowd when you're designing a game, and even harder when you're only working with an indie developer's budget, but somehow Dennaton Games have managed it with Hotline Miami. This is a visceral white knuckle action game condensed into a top down 2D retro throwback that really manages to get under your skin. Whether you're playing for the incredible thumping soundtrack or the cryptic narrative, you'll find something to love - and, more importantly - remember here. Buy it. Now.

Probably one of the best games I've ever played. It does everything near perfect. I've always loved great plots in games, but a lot of the time the game play isn't good enough to pull me through it. In Hotline Miami, The plot is confusing, in a good way. It makes you think hard and find the hidden things to piece it all together. The game play, which in my opinion is the most important part, also is phenomenal. Its a fast paced top down shooter were you only have to hit once to kill but get killed by one hit yourself, making it really based on reflexes. It may be a shooter you will still be using melee weapons a whole lot, possibly even more then the fire arms. Each weapon, while killing in one hit, works different. Some are long and slow, others short and fast. The guns vary from assault rifle and sub machine guns to shotguns and revolvers. To spice up the game play even more, you get a large amount of masks to unlock throughout the missions. Each one will give you different changes, some make all guns have silencers, Others will start you off with a knife, or give insta kill fists. One turns out all lights and gives you night vision making stealth a whole lot easier. Each mask gives you a different play style making replay value huge. The visuals aren't bad either. everything is done in a gorgeous pixel style. There are effects to make the whole thing look like a 80's film. The soundtrack is probably the best I've ever heard in a game, it blends with the game play to give a truly awesome experience. Over all Hotline Miami remains one of my favorite games and I recommend it to all looking to pick it up. Worth every penny you pay.

I can't tell if this game is just super short, and I suck at it, or if it is a decent length. You will probably die and restart hundreds of times, then almost clear a floor and die from a bullet shot from off-screen....gets very frustrating. You end up having to memorize a level and shoot things you cannot possibly see, in some places. Some people will consider this cheap and bad design, others will call it a necessary part of the mechanics.   I paid about $1.50 for this, and really that is all I can say it is worth, but I recommend it at that price point. Yes I got 7 hours out of it, but most of that was replaying the same damn thing over and over, the vast majority of that time.  DO NOT BUY THIS FOR THE STORY. From the clips I have seen, the sequel actually has some interesting narrative in it, you could completely skip this one and buy the sequel without missing any story. This game gives you about 4 lines of text between every level, and it is all meant to be 'cryptic' but ends up being completely meaningless and useless for solving any mystery yourself. You end up knowing about 10% of what the character you are playing as supposedly knows. The game play is: Killing. That’s it. Don't expect any story. It would be nice to say 'you are left with more questions than answers', but no, you are not even left with any questions or answers.  SPOILERS  You play as a couple different guys who get phone calls and then go out to kill people, there are only a few hints at there being a conspiracy behind this. That is all. You could come up with just about any explanation for the events in the game, including it was all a dream, multiple personalities, Russian mafia, a phone company. Who knows? This may actually just have been an introduction for HM2, as the writers could take the story literally anywhere after this. You are never told anything about any of the characers, at all...none of the 'story' in game actually tells the player anything.  Also, the levels are small so replayability is limited. There are more masks that you can unlock that give you special abilities, than the number of times you will be able to stand replaying a level. Not that the mechanics themselves are bad, but for the simplicity of the levels (and the fact that some 'levels' are pretty much in-game cutscenes where you kill unarmed ppl or just do nothing), I would have expected a lot more levels.  I will have to wait until HM2 is under $3...based on this one, I would be very disappointed to have paid full price.

As I've blown through my indie lineup of games, I've often found my own hand reaching toward my back in a patting motion. It isn't only because I've done a good job getting them at bargain price, but because I've been blown away by the constant-surprisingly good quality of them. Now I don't know who to thank, but I've been surprised again by the latest of these: Hotline Miami. Hotline Miami is a top-down adrenaline shooter with an ultaviolence fetish. The player controls the unnamed protagonist as he executes a variety of mercenary missions that remind me of Boondock Saints in their level of crazy one-sidedness. There are dozens of enemies with guns and baseball bats and only one of you. Have at it!  The difficulty is steep but that is alleviated by the predictability of the enemies and the slight penalty for death. It's seriously quick, and you're gonna need it, because you die a lot. But the second you die, an instant reset is available at the press of a button. This 'get-right-back-into-the-action' mechanic gives the player the incentive to try crazy schemes and really helps keep the fast-paced flow. The result is the perfect run, where the player executes a one-man massacre, a symphony of slaughter that leaves me with the warm, fuzzy feeling of overcoming the odds.  Now for what surprised me: Hotline Miami delivers fun mechanics, but it didn't stop there. Also included in this game are some incredibly graphic pixel-art, an extremely catchy soundtrack, and a mind-bending story centering on the themes of ultraviolence, dehumanization, and unnecessary brutality, and it makes for an excellent break between the act-first-think-later gameplay. Hotline Miami didn't have to be the horrifyingly provocative downward spiral that it was, but it was, and I'll be damned if I didn't enjoy every bit of it.

Since I only ever see positive reviews of this game, I'd like to give an opinion as someone who didn't enjoy it as much.  People often compare the game to a movie called Drive, which I know almost nothing about, so maybe that is why I don't appreciate the style as much.  The game is extremely violent. They manage to create some incredibly gruesome scenarios with pretty basic graphics. The game isn't just bloody, it is vicious. For example, you get extra points if you knock a guy down and beat his head in with a pipe than if you just shoot him. If that kind of thing bothers you at all, I'd pass over this game.  The story isn't anything special. I won't ruin it, but if you like stories that make sense or are really fleshed out, you might be disappointed, like I was.  The game is not poorly made at all. It is fast paced and fluid. It forces you to learn how to succeed without holding your hand. You will die over and over again, and respawn almost instantly at the start of the area.  Some people really like the music, but it didn't really appeal to me. It wasn't bad, it just didn't stand out to me.   A lot of people like this game, but it does seem to be overhyped. It's fine if you can get it cheap, but I'd read about it before paying full price.

Hotline Miami is a game that you just have to play.    The game grips you from the start with a wonderful retro art style and catchy electonica. The music does well to set the pace for your rampages through various levels loaded with strategically placed baddies. Twitchy gameplay makes for a gritty experience that compliments the gory nature of the game. Gameplay is quick and ferocious as one wrong move can set you in the path of a very vigilant foe. Once you are spotted there is little time to react before getting blown into a puddled mess. There are a variety of enemies that will keep you on your toes and well placed bosses to keep the gameplay from going stale. Hotline Miami has perks in the form of masks that give you different abilities. These masks do well to put the odds in your favor without giving you an easy ride through each stage. Weapons are plentiful, although if you get too careless you can find yourself wielding an empty ranged weapon or unequipped altogether.  Although Hotline Miami is difficult, it isn't unforgiving. The story can take about 8 hours to complete. There are many challenges within this game to keep you coming back for more. Your rating of each stage can be improved and there is a massive list of masks and weapons to unlock. Limited replay value is not an issue for this indie juggernaut.  Hotline Miami is a great gaming experience. The game is well polished and very impressive for an indie title. If you do not own this title then be sure to pick it up. It is a great game to buy at any price point.   Hotline Miami gets a well deserved 5 out of 5!

Oh, Hotline Miami... Where to even start with you?  I'm gonna try to make this succinct as possible. In a sort of way, this game is like an extremely, EXTREMELY fast-paced Metal Gear... with only base stages and no fluff in between... and said bases being extremely short but extremely dangerous with a huge emphasis on fast action and actually drawing your enemies to you and getting high kill combos, instead of true stealth gameplay. And you die in one hit from everything, though so (generally) do the enemies, so it's... well, yeah, really fast. And you'll be respawning a LOT.  The graphics are a strangely appealing mix of pixels and a kind of hazy ambience. The soundtrack is fantastic and perfectly fits the game. The level of violence I honestly thought would deter me, but like Binding of Isaac before it, once you actually PLAY the game and understand WHY it's that violent it becomes tolerable, and even viscerally entertaining. The story is extremely interesting and totally ♥♥♥♥ed up. The gameplay... is very fun at its core, but with various crash-inducing bugs (and others that force you to restart the game to fix them anyway), and some small luck-based elements that can be a complete drag when you're trying to ace a stage with a high score, it gets far from perfect marks.  A solid 7/10 game overall, I'd say.

Hotline Miami is a fast, brutal, tremendously satisfying game. The plot is weird too, revolving around the main character's steadily deteriorating mental state. It's something vaguely to with your character killling off the Russian mafia in 1980's Miami, but we have nobody's word for it on who exactly he's killing or why. One scene suggests the character is on drugs and this is contributing to his mental decline. The ending is a slightly unsatisfying conclusion to this intrigue, but the game is so fast paced it doesn't register as that much of a problem with me.  Again, this is quibbling. Holy sh**. I did NOT see this coming!  I had certainly heard all about the little indie hit game Hotline Miami and its recent sequel, but from the advertising and the way it was addressed in many videos I watched made me think that it was just a simple top-down kill em' up.  But, boy, was I wrong this time!  Yes, Hotline Miami is all about getting whatever weapons you can to maim, slaughter, and basically kill everyone around you in the fastest way possible. It's designed for you to be quick on your feet, adapt to situations spontaneously, and plan out your actions thoroughly and the control scheme is perfect for this style of gameplay. Hotline Miami is an honestly addicting game. Even if the story sucked, I'd recommend this solely for the fantastic gameplay.  But what about the story? In most videos I'd see on Hotline Miami, I didn't see any that really talked in depth about the story, but it's what really makes this game stand out from the other murder-centric games out in the market today.  See, Hotline Miami has you play as a nameless faceless hitman hired by a mysterious person on the phone to go out and kill as many people in various buildings as you can, and you do that... but the game never lets you settle too comfortably after you successfully spray your enemy's blood across the halls. After you complete a chapter, the music shifts to this strange, dull, and lifeless music and you're left to walk back to your car and take a good long look at every person you had killed on the way.  On top of this, there are several scenes where you encounter three men in a horse, chicken, and owl mask that confront you (and I personally think they are speaking directly towards the player in these scenes) making sure you understand that you are murdering dozens and dozens of people for no reason whatsoever.   As the game goes on, things get more... surreal. People start disappearing in the life of the protagonist, dead bodies start talking to him, and his best friends ends up disappearing suspiciously. The game does a marvelous job at making you confused, isolated, and taken out of the game experience everytime you finish a level. It recognizes that you're playing a game for the satisfaction of murdering people and it knows that it's fun, but it also knows that you should feel guilty for what you're doing.  In some ways, Hotline Miami is comparable to Spec Ops: The Line, one of my favorite games which I just had the pleasure of replaying a couple weeks ago. However, I feel like Spec Ops is the superior game in guilt-tripping you by making you feel ashamed for all the murdering you've done, because it incorporates the story around the gameplay. While you're playing, you'll see the story develops seemlessly in front of you and your consequences will be slowly but surely revealed. In Hotline Miami, it feels like the scenes of gameplay and the scenes for story are separate, save for some levels later in the game.  And that's just me trying to find some sh** to throw at Hotline Miami. This is a great game I've been looking for, but was surprised to find it here. It's got wonderful visuals reminiscent of Vice City, a fantastic 8-bit soundtrack, addicting gameplay, and a gut-punching story. I couldn't be happier with Hotline Miami. If you haven't tried this indie marvel of a game, go check it out! I'm giving it a 9/10.

Ah Hotline Miami, the kingpin in the revival of the cheesy 80's. Synthwave, Kung Fury and many more pieces of media have been piling up nowadays trying to appeal to this lost era of hair spray, neon colors and more computerized music than a disco club. Not everything that has come out of this new genre has been solid, but one of the flagship games in it is Hotline Miami.  The year is 1989 in a mirror universe like WarGame where the Cold War kept getting hotter. Set in Miami, you play as Jacket, a mute war veteran who has joined the secretive 50 Blessings organization and is tasked to begin violent murder sprees on members of the Russian mob. As time goes on, the world begins to lose it's base and soon you're debating if what you're seeing is real. Not exactly a story for the ages, but Hotline Miami intends for it's story to be like that of Drive, it's there but pushed to the side to allow the action.  And yes, the action in Hotline Miami is it's selling point. The best way to put it would be 'Arcade' like. In that it's really tight and always trying to screw you in some benign way. Jacket comes with a list of masks he can wear that give abilities ranging from insta-kill punches, drills and nail-guns or having certain enemies not attack you. Guns are useful, but loud and eat up ammo quickly, while melee weapons are fast, brutal and efficent. Balance these two and you'll breeze through levels.  And the soundtrack. Good gracious god the soundtrack. Artists like El Huervo, MOON, Perturbator and more fill this soundtrack with more synthwave good ness than an episode of Miami Vice. Some tones put you on edge, others serve as the grease that aides your really angry glide through a tougher level, and some are nice and somber for htose moments where you don't care about where or who you are, but all you want to do is think.  Hotline Miami is one of the best indie action games out there, with a special feel to it that not many games can match. The controls are tight, the levels are progressively harder, the music is fantastic and the story is subtle when it needs to and in your face when it must. I'd highly reccomend you buy Hotline Miami, and the soundtrack to boot. It's an 80's rush that not many games have been able to replicate.

Hotline Miami Review  One of the greatest games ever. Playing Hotline Miami is like a nostalgic fever dream. One of my top ten games ever, I cannot recommend it enough (as long as you can stomach the gore and violence, don't worry it's 16-bit-ish).  Although this game is sort of old news now (the sequel has been out for a while), if you haven't played it, get it now. And I suggest you stick to the classic way of playing it, on PC, keyboard and mouse. It has since its original release been ported to nearly every console that can support it but play it on PC. If you use a controller you do not have the freedom of moving the cursor everywhere unless you hold a certain button. If you use mouse you'll have the freedom and precision you'll need and of course you'll have a view of the room if you hold shift.  I'll confess I know very little idea as to what the story is. You play a guy who's always wearing a high school jacket and an animal mask (different masks give you various powerups). You go around the levels and just kill anyone in your way. It is intentionally done in a classic style, one that brings to mind the days of going to the local Blockbuster and bringing pizza home to have a family dinner + movie night. The asthetic and gameplay are just mint.  Even better is the soundtrack. This game introduced me to what is now my favorite music genre, synthwave. If you are unfamiliar, synthwave is basically 80's styled music. There are different subgenres such as pop synthwave, dark synthwave and even vaporwave is a branch of synthwave. I used to have the soundtrack of this game on my phone and I listened to it all the time, commuting to and from work. I have since upgraded my music stereo to a cassette player.  The gameplay, the nostalgia, the graphics, the music, the sheer mindless fun of playing a videogame is all here. I cannot recommend Hotline Miami enough. I can't exactly remember where I first heard of Hotline Miami, but I heard that it was a pretty decent game. So, when the game was on sale, I picked it up and instantly started playing it.  And I fell in love with it.  Well, not at first. The game actually frustrated me early on, especially when the guns were brought into play.  Let's get the semantics out of the way first. Hotline Miami is a top-down twin-stick shooter. The core of the game is composed of entering a building and killing EVERYONE. Or failing to kill everyone, not reacting fast enough, and either getting picked off by gunfire or killed by a baseball bat to the face. To complete your murderous rampage, you have a wide selection of weapons to choose from, ranging from knives and pipes to shotguns and assault rifles. My personal favorite thing is beating everyone to death with a frying pan (to Supertramp's 'Goodbye Stranger'). Don't judge me.  The levels are well designed, lending themselves to planning routes and seeing enemy patrol patterns to find that one opening that leads to victory. However, some of the levels can go on a bit too long, and there are some that I wish were longer. The story, though has next to no replay value (unless you want to replay certain levels, which I do), so that can also be a turn off.  Also (**SPOILERS AHEAD**) one mission really makes me uncomfortable, that being 'Trauma.' I don't feel comfortable controlling a person ho has BRAIN DAMAGE. Not only that, you are also tasked immediately after you return home with the mission 'Assault,' which has you shooting up A POLICE STATION. Not exactly making video games look good here.  But for the missions I have issues with, there are those that I absolutely love. Honorable mention to 'Deadline,' which has you go postal in an office building full of armed goons, but my favorite mission is easily 'Neighbors,' where you ascend the multiple stories of an apartment building, methodically (or sloppily, it's your choice) wasting tons of mooks. Every time I return to this game, I play this mission a few times, just to see how quickly I can run through it. And I haven't even mentioned the artstyle, which looks as if someone took a NES title and infused it with ALL OF THE DRUGS (this takes place in 1989 Miami, so it kinda fits).  So, yeah, I can safely say that this is getting a recommendation. I believe it was the 512th time I died to a wayward dog that this game truly found its way into my heart. This was an experience I will never forget. No other game I have played has come close to this in terms of the 'pick-up-and-play' factor.
